note.stage: The scene is laid in and around the Hartz Mountains.--Time 1600.
Note.--Hertzog is a hideous deformity, with leaden complexion, humped-back, knotted limbs, crooked body and lame.
Von Puffengruntz is corpulent and rubicund.

div.head: Act 1st
div.stage: SCENE I-- A quiet valley at the foot of the Hartz Mountains ; Cottage of Dame Barbara, R. H. 3rd Ent., with practicable upper window and balcony ; Set tree beside cottages, at back Set arbor L.H. 3rd ent. Broken water and low rustic stone bridge or long tail piece, with platform from R to L backed by an extended range of hills or mountain spurs, above which light clouds appear, illuminated by the reflected light of the moon. Shortly after rise of curtain the moonbeams grow faint and the ruddy glow of the rising sun diffuses itself over the clouds and horizon. MUSIC. At rise of curtain--enter Rodolphe at back R. H., he descends, comes forward and after looking cautiously around claps his hands three times beneath the window and conceals himself in the arbor. The upper window opens and Amina appears on balcony.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Surely I heard his well-known signal. Hist! who's there?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Tis I, Rodolphe.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Rodolphe! Hush, speak low, if my foster-mother still sleeps, I will join you. [Retires.]

div.stage: [Music.] Rodolphe goes up stage and looks cautiously off, then comes down. Amina enters from cottage.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Rodolphe!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: My own!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: When did you return?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: 'Twas past midnight: although wearied and footsore I could not sleep until I had seen you.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Oh, how wearily the days and nights have passed since you left me! What kept you so long?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Ill fortune, Amina. After reaching Gottingen, and finding no purchaser for my picture, I heard that there was a wealthy traveller at Cassel, collecting works of art. I had but four silver florins in my pocket, yet I hopefully set out to meet him. After journeying five whole days I arrived at Cassel, only to find that the traveller had departed two days before.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: And your beautiful picture, upon which so much of our future was built, you have brought it back.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: No; crushed in my last hope to obtain the means necessary to our union, I left it with a remorseless agent for a pittance barely sufficient for subsistence during my journey homeward, and here I am, without a single guilder in my pocket, and what is worse, if I fail to redeem my pledge at the end of two months it is lost to me forever.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: [Aside] Poor, dear, Rodolphe, he knows not the worst, the heaviest blow is yet to come, how shall I break it to him; [aloud,] Dear Rodolphe, my great joy at seeing you made me forget for a moment that which I fear to tell you.

div.stage: (The moonlight begins to fade and the horizon grow ruddy with the rising sun.)

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Fear to tell me! Speak, what has happened?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Be calm and Listen. Last week I attended the festival of St. John in company with the other members of the village choir, upon raising my eyes, after we had finished the anthem, I found a dark, strange man gazing upon me; a moment after he quitted the spot. I inquired who he was and learned that it was the Count Wolfenstein, the all powerful lord of this wide domain.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Am,
sp.p: Although I met his gaze but for a moment, I felt that it boded evil to me--to us.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Evil! Evil to us?

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Yes, evil, Rodolphe, nor were my fears idle; the next day brought him here to our humble abode. He told my foster- mother that he loved me.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: [Starting.] Loved! you!--

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Yes, and that we should no longer dwell in obscurity, that we should be removed to the castle, that masters should be provided for my suitable education, and in a year I should take the place of the late Countess of Wolfenstein.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: And Dame Barbara----

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Joyfully consented. This very day is set apart for our removal. The escort will be here at sunrise.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: And you, Amina, you!---

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I supplicated, wept, remonstrated, but you know, dear Rodolphe, I am powerless.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: [Vehemently] By Heaven, you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Hush, be calm, dear Rodolphe.

div.stage: [Dame Barbara appears on the balcony.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: I say you shall not! Were he twenty times more potent I would oppose his power to the last.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Eh, what, varlet, hussey, only wait till I get down! (Music. She disappears from Balcony and enters from door.] What, jade, ingrate! how dare you! Is this your gratitude! Where is your pride! You the most noble Countess of Wolfenstein that is to be meeting young men in secret and on the very day of your bethrothal! Oh, if his high mightiness the Count should find it out!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: But mother --

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Not a word, how dare you; in with you, into the house, in I say! [Forces her into the cottage, closes the door, then turns to Rodolphe] So, beggar, you've come back, have you! How dare you show your unlucky face here at such a time as this! I had hoped you had fallen into the hands of the conscript officers and gone for a soldier, or better still, been carried off by the Demons of the Brocken.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: And yet,as you see, I've escaped both. Hark ye, Dame, I love Amina, she loves me, you, yourself promised that she should be mine as soon as I could command a hundred silver crowns.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Bah, that was before I knew her value, but now that I do know it and others know it too, I've changed my mind. But where are the hundred crowns ; where's the fortune you were to get for your great painting? I warrant me you hav'nt got a single groschen of it. Come, let me see the hundred crowns

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: My picture is not yet sold.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ha, ha! Did I not say so! Not yet sold! Here is a pretty fellow that would take a young girl from her comfortable home, a good bed, sweet milk and egg pudding, to lodge her on peas straw, and feed her at best on black bread and sour cheese. Oh, was there ever such villainy?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Nay, but listen to me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Not a word, begone! Do you think people of quality have nothing to do but listen to beggars complaints and above all at such a time as this. Begone, I say, this is to be a festival day, the maidens of the village will be here anon, the grand escort will be here headed by the Count's chamberlain, aye, and his lordship the Count himself will be here to bear the Countess that is to be and her right honorable foster-mother that is to be to the castle. [Music.] Hark, here come the villagers already, out of the way I say.

div.stage: [Pushes him rudely aside, goes up and looks off, R.H. Rodolphe retires into the arbor.

[Enter lively, from R.H. at back female villagers, with garlands, followed by males, two of whom bear a rustic chair, festooned with flowers, they cross the bridge and come forward, greeting the Dame, females L.H. males R. at back. The sun appears above one of the spurs.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Ah, you are early friends.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes, but not earlier than the sun, for see, it is already peeping over the great toe of the Brocken. But where's Amina?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: [Drawing herself up.] The Countess that is to be is preparing to receive his lordship the Count, but never mind her ladyship.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Bliss me, how grand Dame Barbara has grown to be sure. If she goes on at this rate the wide halls of the grand old castle of Wolfenstein will be a world too small to hold her. I hope this piece of good fortune will not make such a fool of dear 'Mina

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I don't understand this. I thought 'Mina was bethrothed to the handsome young painter Rodolphe, whatever could have become of him?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis said he has gone for a soldier. But come, while 'Mina is making ready let us rehearse our Festival Dance.

div.stage: [Music: Grand Garland Dance by principals and full Ballet, during which the Males gather around the table and eat and drink. After dance, Barbara re-enters extravagantly dressed, wearing a monstrous cap, ridiculously trimmed)

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: There! Having completed her ladyships toilet I have attended to my own, and if I know anything about dress I flatter myself that my appearance would do honor to any occasion. [Displays herself.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Mercy on us, was there ever such a fright! Why she looks for all the world like a great horned owl, dressed up in the cast-off finery of a peacock. Ha, ha, ha! did you ever! Observe me tickle the old buzzard. [Aloud and with affected admiration.] Why, Dame Barbara! is that you!

sp.speaker: Bar.
Car.
sp.p: Why, you've almost taken away my breath! I declare Dame, you're looking gorgeous; so young and girlish, too, indeed, if I were 'Mina--I beg pardon, I mean her ladyship, I wouldn't care to have her in the way when his lordship the Count arrives.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And why not pray!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Because I should consider you a dangerous rival.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Nonesense, girl, you don't think so.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Indeed, Dame Barbara, I was never more serious in my life. [Laughingly confers with Rosetta and villagers.]

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: It is strange I never noticed it before, but that girl Caroline is a very sensible person. [Music.] Ah, here comes the escort!
sp.stage: [All go up and look off R.H.--Rodolphe glides from the arbor into the cottage unobserved.

div.stage: [Enter from R.H. and crossing the bridge, Von Puffengruntz, bearing his wand of office, preceded by two servants of the Count's household, as he comes down the Male Villagers take off their caps, and the females curtsey

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: (L.H.) [With pompous consideration.] Be covered, good people, be covered, the air of the valley is yet damp, we never insist upon ceremony at the expense of health. [Aside.] Ahem! It is the true policy of greatness to occasionally waive a point of etiquette on dealing with inferiors.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: What a courtly gentleman!

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: What an imposing female!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: [Curtseying.] Your Excellency is welcome.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: I cannot be mistaken. I was just about to inquire, but that stately presence and graceful dignity tell me that I am addressing Madam Barbara.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: (Curtseying) Oh, sir. [aside.] How one's manner will betray one. I always said I belonged to a higher sphere.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: I come, Madam, by the Count's order, to announce that the cavalcade has arrived and is now resting on the plateau beyond the ravine. His lordship will be here presently, and in person conduct your fair foster-daughter to her palfrey, that waits without, impatient for the honor to be mounted by her.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh, sir, his lordship is so considerate. But, may I inquire if I have been thought of? Am I, also to be provided with a becoming escort? Is there any palfrey without impatient for the honor to be ridden by me.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: That shall be my privilege

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: [Astonished.] Eh!

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: That is, I have charged myself with the especial happiness of being your escort.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: [Curtseying very low. Oh! [Music.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: He comes! Room there for his lordship!
sp.stage: [Villagers range themselves to receive the Count who enters R.H. crosses the bridge, preceded by guards and followed by Wulfgar and Bruno. When down L.H. Villagers shout and wave their caps

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: Salutation to the good Dame Barbara.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: [Curtseying very low. Oh, your lordship.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: And how fares your lovely charge?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Well, may it please your lordship, quite well, a little nervous from over anxiety to see your lordship, but that is quite natural with us, poor silly things ; I suffered dreadfully in that way when my poor dear, dead and gone Christopher courted me, many and many a time---

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: [Interrupting her.] But the fair Amina.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Is quite ready and dying to see you. I will present her to your lordship at once.
sp.stage: [She is going into the cottage when Rodolphe appears and comes forward, leading Amina by the hand. Chord.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Allow me, Dame Barbara, to do the honors.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Rodolphe! [Picture of astonishment.]

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: My lord, Count Wolfenstein, permit me, Rodolphe Werner, a poor artist, to present to you Amina, foster-daughter to Dame Barbara--a free maiden of the valley and my affianced bride.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: Who is this madman?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: N-n-n-n-nobody your lordship, that is a poor, weak simpleton, who imagines he is betrothed to every girl in the village-- as your lordship truly says, a madman.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: A madman! mercy on us, we shall all be murdered! Seize him, secure him, somebody, everybody.

div.stage: [Music. Wulfgar and Bruno seize Rodolphe, and after a struggle overpower him. Amina screams and throws herself at the Count's feet, he raises and passes her to Barbara, then turns to guards.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: Release him. [They release him.] His misfortune claims our pity. Let some of his fellows conduct him hence, and see that no harm come to him.

sp.speaker: Rodo.
sp.p: My Lord Count!--

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: Begone, sirrah!

sp.speaker: Casp.
sp.p: Come, Rodolphe, come with me. [Aside.] Are you indeed mad to brave the tiger in his lair. [Leads him R.H.] Come, I say, this is neither time nor place to right your wrong. Be calm, I say, be calm.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: [Shaking his hand.] You are right, Casper, you are right. [Looks scornfully at Wolfenstein.] Come, my friend, come. [Exit R.H. 1st Ent. with Casper.]

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: 'Tis he, the lover! He braves me, too.
Wulgar!
Track younder knave ; take Bruno with you ; seize him, but let no eye see you ; place him in the secret vault beneath the eastern wing ; once there, you know the rest.

sp.speaker: Wul.
sp.p: [Nods meaningly.] I understand. [Gives sign to Bruno, and is going R.H. 1st ent.]

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: Stay, not now, it will be noted. When the procession moves, then steal away by the upper path

div.stage: [Wulfgar nods, turns up and confers with Bruno. Wolfenstein confers with Von Puffengruntz at back.]

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
[Leading Amina forward, and aside to her.]
Silence, on your life ; not a word that you have ever seen him before. If the Count were to know--Mercy on me, I tremble to think of it--there wouldn't be a head left on any of our shoulders.

div.stage: [Birds are heard singing till scene closes.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: [Waving his wand.] Let the procession move.

div.stage: [Music. Wolfenstein joins Amina. Villagers bring foward the festooned chair from L.H.N.E.; Wolfenstein assists Amina into the seat ; the chair is borne by four villagers ; the others form in procession, Wolfenstein beside the chair, Von Puffengruntz pompously leading Barbara by the hand ; Wulfgar and Bruno loiter behind, and when unobserved steal off R.H.N.E. ; the procession, after making the circuit of the stage, ascends the rocks L.H. and crosses R., the villagers singing the following

lg.l: Hark! the birds with tuneful voices,
And the lips of op'ning flowers
Breathe their incense on the air,
Breathe their incense on the air.
See the sun in orient splendor
For our lovely Queen of May,
For our lovely Queen of May.
Mark the plumes of mighty Brocken

div.stage: [Closed in when Amina is in the center of bridge.]

div.head: SCENE 2.--A dark woody or rocky pass. Lights half down.
div.stage: [Music. Enter Wulfgar and Bruno R.H.)

sp.speaker: Wul.
sp.p: So ; we've reached the pass a good five minutes before him.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: But if he should cross the bridge?

sp.speaker: Wul.
sp.p: Aye, if, but he'll not. I watched him from behind "The Devil's Hump" and saw him part company with that lout at the foot of the old cross. I tell you his path lies this way. [Crosses to L.H.] Hark ! some one comes. [Looks cautiously off.] Ha! I was right : 'tis he. Quick, conceal yourself, and when I hood the hawk stand ready to clip his claws.
sp.stage: [Music. Wulfgar conceals himself L.H. Bruno R.H.

div.stage: Music. Enter Rodoplhe, L.H.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Deeper, let me plunge deeper still into the heart of the mountain. The light of the sun falls like molten lead upon my aching eyeballs. My heart's on fire ; my brain is in a whirl: I strive to think, but thought becomes a chaos Am I awake, or is this some horrible dream? Water, water: my throat is flaming. Ha! yonder is a rill trickling from the rock.

div.stage: [Music. He is going R. when Wulfgar, who has stolen from his concealment, throws a cloak over his head, while Bruno at the same moment pinions his arms, Rodolphe struggling violently

sp.speaker: Wul.
sp.p: Quick, quick--the cord, the cord. He has the strength of a lion. [Bruno draws a cord tightly over his arms.] So ; away. away.

div.head: SCENE 3.--Study and laboratory of the Black Crook (in 2.) Hertzog discovered LH, seated at table, pouring over a large cabalistic book. Greppo, pinched and starved, asleep on stool R.C. before a retort furnace on R.H. flat. An antique lamp illuminates the characters of the book upon the table, upon which is a skull and hour-glass. Door LH flat. Music at opening of scene.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.stage: [Rising in pain and with difficulty, he closes the book and comes forward.]
sp.p: Vain, vain! Some subtle spell is hovering in the air that mocks my power and makes the charms which once were potent a gibbering, idle sound. And shall I yield to this Invisible? I, Hertzog the Crook, whom men call sorcerer. I, at whose name the strong man trembles and the weak grows faint. I, whose whole life of long, laborious years hath well nigh run its course, gleaning dark knowledge in forbidden paths-- shall I now seek the light? My eyes are old and weak, and could not brave the glare. No, no, I'll work new mines, new mines, and plumb the depths of darker mysteries still. [Greppo snores loudly. Hertzog turning.] How now, knave?[Greppo starts from his sleep and uses the bellows rapidly at the mouth of the furnace.] Come hither, varlet.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Yes, master. [Puts down the bellows, and comes forward yawning)

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: What, drone, sluggard, drowsing again?

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: N-n-n-no, good master, no.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Out, lying knave, did I not hear thee snore?

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Snore! Aye, granted; but 'twas in thy service, master. Much fasting and long watching caused this left, rebellious eye to wink, and so I snored to wake it up again.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Bah! shuffling loon, thy drowsing comes of overfeeding.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: [Viewing himself.] Overfeeding? Look I if I were overfed? A scanty chopin of weak sour beer, with one poor groschen's worth of musty beans is all the banquet this shrunk belly knows from week to week.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: What, rogue, dost grumble?

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: No, good master, no.

div.stage: [Rumbling thunder. Music--Tremulo piano

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Ha! the night grows foul ; 'Tis all the better, Bring me my cloak and staff. [Thunder.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: [Bringing forward crutch, stick and short, black, hooded cloak from nail in flat They are here. (Places cloak on Hertzog's shoulders.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: So ; now thine own.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: My cloak ? I have none, Master.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Thy cap.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Mine?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Thine. [Thunder.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Oh, Lord! what a night, [Brings his cap from peg beside the furnace.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Bring with thee yonder brazen casket.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Th-the-the brazen casket?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Aye, echoing fool! [Thunder.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: [Tremblingly goes to table and takes casket. Aside.] The devil's tool-chest! [Aloud] Whither go we, dread master?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: To the Serpents' Glen. (Loud thunder)

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p:
[Starting.] Oh, Lord! the Serpent's Glen! Beelzebub's favorite chapel! surely, good master, you would not, and above all on such a night as this?
[Thunder and lightning, the latter showing itself in transparent window in flat.] Hark ! how the tempest howls; strong pines are toppling down the mountain sides. 'Twere certain death to go abroad to-night.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Silence, and follow. [Goes toward door. Lightning and loud thunder.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p:
[Who has made a movement to follow, starts back, trembling violently.]
Master, I--I cannot.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: [Turning fiercely.] What, ingrate, do you rebel?

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: No, master, no; my spirit is willing, but my legs are weak.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Wretch, did I not snatch thee drowning from the whirling gulf, bind thy torn limbs with rare medicaments, and staunch the current of thy ebbing life that fast wast running out?

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: You did, good master, you did. [Aside.] Out of the water into the fire.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p:
Begone.
[Music forte. Throws upon the door in L.H. flat. Loud crashing thunder and & vivid lightning. Greppo starts back. Fool, begone, I say. (Seizes and hurls him toward the open door. Heavy thunder & lightning. Greppo in doorway entreats. Hertzog, raising his staff.] Away, away! [Thunder & lightning. Exeunt door L. H. flat.

div.div:
SCENE 4.-- An apartment in the castle of Wolfenstein. (in 1.) Low thunder. Lights up.
Enter Carline, R. H.
Car.
Bless me, what a night to welcome her ladyship that is to be to her new home. I declare, the old castle trembles and shakes like a great ship at sea. [Loud thunder.] Mercy on us, what a crash! But pshaw, why should I care how the tempest rages without? am I not safe within, and in rare good luck, too? Only to think that I should be chosen from among all the girls of the village to become Amina's companion and own particular waiting maid. Old Hagar, the Gipsy fortune teller, whose palm I crossed with a new quarter florin last week, at the festival, told me that good fortune awaited me, and sure enough, here it is. Only to think of it, that I, Carline Brenner, who for ten long years have been chained to a stupid spinning-wheel, day and night should become confidential companion to the future mistress of Wolfenstein! Was there ever such good fortune? I declare, I'm so happy I could sing for a month.
[Introduced song, and exit L.H.

div.head: SCENE 5.-- a wild glen in the heart of the Brocken. Perilous rocky pathway leading from above at back L. H. to stage ; returning, crossing over a rock five feet high R. H. 3d ent., with set blasted tree ; large working raven on limb, and vampyre doors in trunks. Set rock piece in C. on stage opposite 2nd grooves, bearing a general resemblance in outline to a rude altar. Set trick plants with serrated leaves R. & L. The whole stage is much broken up with rocky sets, leaving the center, back of the altar, generally open. Lights down. Music at opening. HERTZOG appears above L.H., followed by GREPPO tremblingly. They cross from L. to R.. re-cross on rock in front of blasted tree and descend slowly ; GREPPO making several efforts to turn back is checked, by a gesture from HERTZOG.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: [Coming forward L.H. when down.] Oh, Lord! what a place! [Music. The raven croaks, flaps its wings and shows red, illuminated eyes. Starting.] What's that? [Turns] 'Twas the croaking of yonder monk-raven. Did'st hear, master? 'Tis an evil sign. Let's begone.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Silence, fool ; set down the casket. [Goes up stage.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: I will. [Places the casket on ground, L.C.] Thank Saint Michael, I'm rid of that pleasant companion. As I have an empty belly, and hope some day to have it filled, I could swear before the Burgomaster that when we passed over the bridge of Belzebub's Nose, I heard voices laughing inside that very casket, saw blue blazes come out of the key-hole, and smelt a strong smell of brimstone. [Music. The raven croaks as before. Looking fearfully around. Oh, Lord ! oh, Lord! what a pleasant place for an uninterrupted funeral. Ugh!

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Knave.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Master?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Bring hither fuel.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: I obey. [Aside.] Here's a chance, if I can only get out of this, may the fiend singe me if he catches me back. I'd rather be in the raging flood again than serve him an hour longer. [Is about to ascend the rocks.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Whither go you, varlet?

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: For fuel, master; this around us is wet with the storm and will not burn. As we came along I noted, beneath the shelter of a crag hard by, many dry faggots. I will fetch them. [Going.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p:
Come back.
[Greppo groans and returns. Hert. pointing R. H. 2d ent.] The dead branches of yon blasted larch will serve.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: But, master--

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Dolt, obey me.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: I'm gone! [Groans and exits R.H. 2d ent.

div.stage: Music. Hertzog goes slowly up to set altar and smites it three times with crutch stick. Blue flame issues from the top and continues during the scene.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Here are the faggots, master.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: 'Tis well. Feed yonder flame.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: A flame! How came we by a flame? I'll swear I brought no tinder-box. More brimstone, I suppose. Oh, Lord! oh, Lord!

sp.speaker: Herzog
sp.p: Fool, do as I command.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: I fly.
sp.stage: [Music. He goes slowly and timidly up to and behind altar with faggots.]
sp.p: Now for some devil's cookery.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p:
So. Pluck me an inner leaf from yonder adder plant.
[Points to plant L.H.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: I knew it--vegetable broth.

div.stage: [Music. He approaches the plant L. H., and is about to pluck a leaf, when it opens suddenly and discovers a dwarf demon, around whose body is twined a huge green serpent, with flaming eyes, distended jaws and forked tongue. As the leaves open, the head darts at Greppo threateningly. He starts back, uttering a cry of alarm. The leaves close.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Ha!
sp.stage: [Stamps his foot angrily, and points to the plant R.H.. Greppo tremblingly crosses R.H., and is about to pluck a leaf from the plant, when it opens, and the same action of dwarf, demon, serpent and Greppo as before. Leaves close.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: So, so. Bring me the green flagon from yonder casket. [Music. Greppo goes to the casket L.H. and raises the lid, when fire flashes from the box. He starts back in an agony of fright and crossing, sits upon the small set rock piece R.H. 1st ent., when flames shoot from the stone, and he springs into the air, uttering a sharp cry of pain.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Baffled at every turn! Begone, knave, thy presence mars my work.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Most willingly. [Is about to ascend the rocks.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Not there. [GREPPO groans and returns.] Keep watch without from yonder crag that overhangs the gorge. [Points R.H. 1st ent.] Should stragging footsteps bend this way, give timely warning.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: [Aside.] Straggling footsteps! straggling, indeed, to be abroad on such a night, and least of all in such a place as this.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Did'st hear me?

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p:
I vanish
[Exit R.H. 1st ent.

div.stage: [Music. Hertzog describes a circle and figures on the ground (c) with his crutch stick, after which the end of the stick ignites and burns with a faint blue flame. He then describes figures in the air, during which latter action he speaks.]

sp.speaker: Hertz.
sp.p: Skuldawelp! Familiar slave of my power, I invoke thee.

div.stage: [Music. A spectre in filmy drapery with Death's head, luminous eyes, moveable jaw and skeleton hands works on from R.H.N.E to C. Illuminated by light from medium.]

sp.speaker: Skul.
sp.p: Your will.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Break the malignant spells that thwart and mock me. Bind fast my hidden enemies. Restore to me my lost power.

sp.speaker: Skul.
sp.p: I cannot. An adverse spell has crossed me ; my power is spent. All that was mine is thine. Zamiel alone can serve thee.

sp.speaker: Herzog
sp.p: [Shrinking.] Zamiel?

sp.speaker: Skul.
sp.p: Zamiel. Dismiss me.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p:
[Waving his staff.] Begone! [Music. Skuldawelp glides off L.H.] Zamiel! No, no. I dare not invoke his fearful aid.
[Music--tremulo piano.] I--I, ha! what tremor's this? My blood grows icy cold, my limbs are failing, a film is gathering in my eyes.
[Falls C.]
Can this be death? Death! No, no. I cannot, I will not die! Save me, save me, Zamiel! Zamiel!
[Music forte. He drags himself toward the casket, seizes it, rises with difficulty and totters to the altar, at the foot of which he places the casket, opens it and brings forth a packet containing four lesser packets, and begins the following

lg.stage: [He casts red ingredients into the fire. Wild blast of demoniacal music. The raven croaks, flaps its wings and shows its illuminated eyes ; the leaves of the adder plants open, and disclose demons and serpents as before; skeleton forms appear above on rocks, pointing to Hertzog. Music changes to tremulo piano. The adder plants remain open throughout the rest of the scene)

[Casts green ingredient into the fire. [Wild blast of demoniacal music and same action as before. Music changes to tremulo piano A huge green serpent with moveable jaw, rises from the flame behind the altar as each packet is thrown in and strikes at Hertzog.
lg.l: By the thief with skulking tread,
Who breaks the grave and robs the dead;
lg.stage: [Casts blue ingredients into fire. Wild blast and same action as before. Music changes to tremulo piano.
lg.l: BY all the crimes men hate and fear,

div.stage: [Wild blast and same action as before, in addition to which loud crashing thunder and vivid lightning, the latter showing in luminous forks in backing. Huge serpents writhe to and fro across the stage. Zamiel, bearing a sceptre, around which is twined a green serpent, suddenly appears from trunk of blasted tree, with strong light from red medium thrown upon him. He holds the picture a moment before speaking. Hertzog kneeling down, L.H. Music ceases.

sp.speaker: Zam,
sp.p: Arise. [Hertzog arises.] Why am I summoned?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: My life is waining. Give me to live ; feed the dull currents of my sluggish veins ; give me fresh charms and potencies.

sp.speaker: Zam.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Men hate, and, did they not fear, would despise me. I would repay their hate with hate ; I would live on, on, on, and in that life rival thy dread power of evil.

sp.speaker: Zam.
sp.p: What wilt thou give for such a boon?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Whate'er thou wilt. Give me but life, and all I have is thine.

sp.speaker: Zam.
sp.p: 'Tis not enough ; what's thine is mine already.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Zam.
sp.p: Listen. A soul--younger, fresher, whiter than thine--must on each recurring year, be, by thy arts, turned to my account.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: I hear, dread master, and will pay the price.

sp.speaker: Zam.
sp.p: For every soul thus lost to good and gained to me, a year's new life is thine. A single soul, a single year ; a hundred souls, a hundred years. 'Tis with thyself to live forever!

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Forever?

sp.speaker: Zam.
sp.p: Forever. But should the stroke of midnight fall a twelvemonth hence and no lost soul by you betrayed within that time come wailing at my gates, perdition closes on your dark career. Is't a compact?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: It is.

div.stage: [Music. Zamiel waves his sceptre. Thunder and lightning. A fiend, Redglare, rises at Hertzog's elbow through trap LH2, bearing a large red book, pen and inkhorn.)

sp.speaker: Zam.
sp.p: (Pointing to book) Sign!

div.stage: (Music. Thunder and lightning. Sheeted spectres arise through traps at back and appear at R. & L from behind rocks. Skuldawelp re-appears L.H. 3rd ent. Demons appear from R & L, all pointing to Hertzog who takes the pen and dips it in the horn ; the pen ignites and flames blue. He writes in the book, during which the raven croaks, flaps its wings, &c.; serpents writhe to and fro across stage, and demoniacal laughter is heard outside and above, after which Zamiel waves his sceptre, gong sounds and Redglare descends with book, &c., amid red fire. Music stops.

sp.speaker: Zam.
sp.p: 'Tis well. Listen, slave. Within a dungeon of the eastern wing of gray and gloomy Wolfenstein, there lies in chains a youth called Rodolphe. His fortune's desperate, and desperate souls, like drowning men, will catch at straws. Begin with him.

sp.speaker: Herzog
sp.p: Dread power. I hear thy mandate and thy will obey.

div.stage: [Bows low before Zamiel.

[Music. Thunder & lightning and all the action as before. Red fire from behind the altar and at the wings. Redglare appears R.H. 2d. ent., pointing. Winged serpents appear above and firey dragon enters L.H.2d ent., simultaneous with which Greppo, very white, rushes on R.H.1st ent. as if to communicate something.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Master, I--

div.stage: [Is appalled at the sight before him, utters a loud cry, falls upon his knees, clasping his hands and moving his lips rapidly, as if in prayer.

div.head: ACT 2
div.stage: Scene 1.--A subterranean vault beneath the castle of Wolfenstein. (in 2.) Set floor R.H.N.E. moveable panel in upper part of R.H. flat ; sliding stone panel in lower part of L.H. flat. Wulfgar discovered chaining Rodolphe to wall of R.H. flat. Music at rise of curtain. Lights half down.

sp.speaker: Wul.
sp.p: There, my fine fellow. I think you're both safe and comfortable. No intrusion, neither light nor sound, ever come here. This should have been your lodging last night, but you see I mislaid the key.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Wretch.

sp.speaker: Wul.
sp.p: When you want exercise or change of air, and you can manage to get out of yonder little encumbrances [pointing to chains], you can take it in the vault beneath your feet. Yonder trap leads to it. You may find it a little mouldy, and may stumble over the skeleton of the last lodger. But that's nothing ; any change is better than no change at all.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Monster, begone.

sp.speaker: Wulfgar
sp.p: Oh certainly--anything to oblige. In the meantime, if your exercise should give you an appetite, and you should want food and water, cry out for it--cry loud and it wont come. Ha, ha ha! Good night.

div.stage: [Exits R.H. door. Lights down.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Alone! So ends in darkness and in death all my bright dreams of the future. And must I perish thus--I, who have but entered the portal of life? No, no, it cannot be! I must, I will burst these bonds. [Music. He makes an effort to break the chains.] 'Tis vain, they defy even the strength of despair. [Shuddering.] How awful is the chill of this noxious vault ; its icy vapors press upon my brow like the clammy hand of death, and freeze my very marrow.

div.stage: [Music. Hertzog enters with dark lantern through sliding panel in L.H. flat.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Thy friend.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.stage: [Turning the light of the lantern upon his own face.]
sp.p: Behold!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: [Starting.] Hertzog, the Crook!

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Aye, so men call me. [Puts down lantern off L.H.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Ill-omened bird, what brings you here? Yet why should I ask? You come the minister of Death. 'Tis well, 'tis merciful-- begin your work.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Out, foolish boy. I serve no human master.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Then why are you here?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: I come to give thee liberty.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Liberty?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Aye. Listen. I hate thine enemy. Thou lov'st a maid of whom Thou lov'st a maid of whom thou hast been robbed. Would'st win her back? I have the power to aid thee.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Begone, tempter. I know your power, and can guess from whence it comes. Men say you deal in dark and necromantic spells that warp the senses and enthral the soul.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Bah! Art thou, too, tainted with the vulgar fear that calls philosophy--the natural working of great nature's laws--a spell of darkness? It is the light, weak boy, the light, which we sage men, who waste our lives oe'r midnight lamps glean from dull vapors for sluggards' use. Fools sneer the most when least they understand, and brand as foul what nature stamps as fair. Thy gains gall thee ; let me loose them. [He touches them with his staff; they fall to the ground.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: [Surprised.] What is your purpose?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Again I say, to serve thee.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Listen, I will tell thee a secret. She whom thou lovest is of noble birth.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Amina?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Aye, yet not Amina, but the only child and heiress of the noble house of Wellenstein--stolen when but an infant by a revengeful Gipsy whom her father scourged, and given to gabbling Barbara.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Amina noble?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Aye, and thou of humble birth. But gold can buy nobility ; nay more, can give thee power to cross thine enemy.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Why talk to me of gold?--to me, the poorest of the poor, whose purse contains not half so much as one poor silver mark.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Thou'rt poor indeed, but thou art poor because thou wilt be poor. 'Tis with thyself to shame the wealth of mighty Croesus.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Hast thou not heard of glittering gold in massive piles fast locked within these mountains?

sp.speaker: Rod.
Hert.
sp.p: I tell thee, boy, the story's true, this gold is palpable to sight and touch, and may be garnered, too, if thou art bold enough.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: I'll hear no more! Thou'dst take advantage of my desperate strait to work some juggle to entrap my soul. Begone, I say, begone!

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: And leave thee to thy doom?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: And thy affianced bride--would'st thou so like a craven yield her up unto thine enemy?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Oh, agony!

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: 'Tis true she loves thee ; but bethink thee, boy, she is but woman, and she may be won. Her noble birth is known to Wolfenstein, who means to wed her, and with her fortune prop his falling house. Already, flattered by his serpent tounge, she dries her tears and listens to his suit.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: 'Tis false!

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: 'Tis true!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: The proof?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Behold!
sp.stage: [Music. He waves his staff; a panel slides in upper part of R.H. flat slides open, showing through gauze Wolfenstein and Amina, the former clasping the hand and kneeling at the feet of the latter whose face is half averted. Picture strongly lighted)

sp.speaker: Rod,
sp.p: [Starting toward it.] By Heaven, he shall not!

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: [Interposing; waves his staff; panel closes.] Bravely said, bravely said.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: (Turning quickly) What dev'lish compact would you have me sign? Propose it while my reason whirls and desperation aids your dam'd design. If by the act I snatch her from his grasp, I'll pay the ransom though it reach my soul. [Hertzog, with face averted, chuckles sardonically) Come, philosopher or fiend, whate'er thou art; the price, I say, the price.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Pah! I ask no compact. I would serve thee gratis. I but demand that thou shalt serve thyself. Be rich and thou'lt be powerful. In thy revenge upon thine enemy and mine, thou'lt pay thy debt to me with interest.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Where lies this wondrous treasure?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Listen. Amid the fastnesses of the Hartz, beyond the outlet of the Black Gorge, lies a small lake whose waters few have ever gazen upon, for vulgar fear and superstitious dread have long since marked it for enchanted ground.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: I've heard the story.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p:
Trace carefully its northern shore until a rock rising like a wall bars further passage. Beneath a fringe of tangled vines you'll find a boat concealed. Behold this talismanic ring!
[Takes a large ring from his finger.]
'Tis a magnet of wondrous power. When thou hast found the boat step boldly in, this ring will guide thee safely to the entrance of the goldern cavern, within the compass of whose glittering walls thy wondering eyes may feast on wealth far greater than the coffers of the world can boast.

sp.speaker: Rod,
sp.p: Give me the ring.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: 'Tis thine. [gives it.] Stay, thou'lt need a henchman, [stamps his foot.] Varlet, come forth. [Panel in L.H. flat slides as before and Greppo enters. [aside.] He too shall perish.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Your will, Master?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: To part with three.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: [Aside.] Oh, if this should be true. [aloud] With me!

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: With thee, knave.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: I weary with thine appetite.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: [Aside.] Here's a chance! Oh, here a chance, if he but stick to it. I must seem unwilling lest he repent, [Aloud] Dear master, I will reform, believe me, I will reform, allowance me to what would starve a mouse, nay, more, to pleasure you I will not eat at all. I'll live on air, but do not cast me off.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: I am resolved. Behold thy future master. [to Rodolphe.] Thou'lt find him faithful but he breeds a famine. Take for thy present need this purse of gold. [offers purse; Rodolphe by a gesture refuses it.] May, when thou art rich thou can'st repay it.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: [Taking purse.] Nay, more, if what you say be true, eternal gratitude--

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Bah, you trifle time. [Waves his staff, panel opens.] yonder lies your path, it is a glorious one, begone!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Farewell. Come, boy, come. [Music. Exit at panel. Greppo following turns to entreat Hertzog, who raises his staff threateningly; Greppo exits hurriedly at panel.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: [Standing in opening and chuckling gazes at them.] The thought of vegeance stirs within his heart, the lust of gold is rising in his soul, the path that leads to where 'tis hoarded ends in death. He's mine! Ha, ha, he's mine!]

div.head:
Scene II.-A lobby in the castle of Wolfenstein. [in 1)
Enter BARBARA R.H., followed by CARLINE.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Don't talk to me, girl, remember your station and consider mine. Who am I and what am I that I should be lodged in a wing of the castle overlooking the dog kennels.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Your ladyship is quite right to rebel, and when I advised your ladyship to calm yourself, it was out of consideration for your ladyships eyes--any little flurry does so spoil the natural beauty of their expression.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Carline, you're a good girl, you're a considerate girl, and I forgive you; but eyes or no eyes. I'll not be imposed on. Where's Mynheer Von Puffengruntz? Where's his lordship's chamberlain?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
[Looking L.H.] Here he comes down the great stairway, as full of flesh and scant of breath as ever.
[aside], and as the waddling old porpoise appears to have a liquorish tooth for this silly old buzzard, I'll leave them to bill and coo, while I run off to comfort dear 'Mina who has passed the whole night in tears for poor Rodolphe.

div.stage: [Von Puff. enters L.H., Carline courteseys and exits L.H.]

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Eh! what! madam Barbara, stirring so early? Why, bless my soul, the mist of the mountain is yet hanging upon the turrets of the castle.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Then let it hang, and be hanged to it! Stirring, indeed! Havn't I been stirring all night? Hasn't her ladyship been stirring all night, and wouldn't the Seven Sleepers have been stirring all night, too, if they had lodged where I did?

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Surely nothing has had the audacity to disturb the quiet of your slumbers?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Nothing! To begin with, do you call such a storm as that of last night nothing? Why, the thunder creashed over the castle loud enough to wake the dead. That was bad enough, but only to think that I, the right honorable foster-mother that is to be, to her right honorable ladyship that is to be, passing the night in apartments overlooking a dog-kennel.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: A dog-kennel!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Aye, a kennel of great, savage hounds, fed late at night with raw meat by their one-eyed keeper, on purpose to give them the night-mare and make them dream all night long of chasing wild boars in the forest. Ugh! I shall never get their horrible yelping out of my head.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Believe me, my dear Madam Barbara, it is the first time the brutes were ever known to have been unruly. I promise you that they shall be soundly punished and instantly removed. But I, too, am criminal. The apartments were selected by me because they commanded the best view of the mountain.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: But I don't want to look at the mountain. I got a glimpse of it from one of the north windows last night during the storm, and it looked for all the world as if Belzebub and his imps were holding a jubileee there.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Enough, my dear Madam Barbara, enough! If the mountain is unpleasant, it shall be removed. No, no, I--I mean you shall be removed. [Approaching her in a wheedling manner.] Will it please you to accompany me and choose for yourself?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: [Simperingly.] Really, mynheer Von Puffingruntz, you have such mollifying ways that--that--

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: [Taking her hand.] Oh!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Would it be prudent! Dare I trust myself? We poor silly things are so weak, and you men are so naughty, that--that-- [leans her head upon his shoulder, looks up into his face and sighs.]

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Confiding innocence, rely upon the honor of a Von Puffengruntz. [Looks around, sighs, kisses her. She utters a faint scream, and, hiding her face in her fan, is led off L.H. by Von Puffengruntz, chuckling.]

div.head: Scene III.--A wild pass in the Hartz mountains, (in 1). [Music at change of scene. Lights down.] Enter R.H. Rodolphe and Greppo, each bearing an Alpine staff. Greppo in improved condition.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: A strange, weird place, and one, it seems, not often trod by human footsteps. I fear we've missed the way. What think you, master Greppo?

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Master Greppo! Master Greppo! He calls be master Greppo! Here's an honor, and here's a master! Oh, such a master! Such a liberal master--as this stuffed belly, tight as any drum with goodly provender and generous wine, will testify. [To Rodolphe.] What think I, princely master?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Why, since you honor me with consultation, and give me leave to think at all--a privilege grown rusty from great lack of use-- I say we're right, and that the lake we seek is near at hand.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Why think you so?

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Because just now I heard a bittern cry, and twice ere that I heard a marsh-frog croak, and as they're both accounted water-fowl, 'twere safe to say we're near the water.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Then let us on. [Crossing to L.H.] Ere long the rising moon will pierce this veil of mist and light us to our golden haven. Come. [Exit L.H.]

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: I follow

div.stage: [Exit L.H. Change very slowly.]

div.head: Scene IV.--The Grotto of Golden Stalactites. A grand and comprehensive water-cavern of gold, deeply perspective, with stalacti-form arched roof. Cut wings representing vistas running parallel and harmonizing with that of the main grotto, the mouth of which [5 feet high and 5 feet wide] discloses an open lake or bath and distant shore at back. Set transparent silver waters, in which are seen sporting fishes and nondescript amphibea. Diminutive fairies asleep in the waters of the grotto in golden shells. Set ground or shore piece richly studded with gold and jewels. Set masses of emerald and gold R. L. and C. upon and at the foot of which are reclining gnomes and amphibea. Fairies asleep in poses R. and L. The moon--seen through opening at back and over the distant shore of the lake--shows red at the opening of scene. [Music at change. Shortly after which, Dragonfin, who has been asleep on a jewelled mass on the shore (C.), slowly awakens, rises, and stretches himself. Upon turning he sees the red upon the face of the moon. Music chord.]

sp.speaker: Drag.
sp.p: Awake! awake!
sp.stage: [Music. Hurry. Gnomes and amphibea spring to their feet. Fairies and water-nymphs enter hurriedly R. & L. Diminutive sprites in the shell awaken.]
sp.p: Behold! there's blood upon the face of the moon! Our Queen's in danger! To arms! to arms!

div.stage: [Music. Hurry. The sprites in the shells disappear R & L. The gnomes, amphibea and fairies rush off R. and L. and immediately reappear, armed--the two first named with knotted clubs and tridents, the fairies with javelins. During the action the red disappears from the face of the moon, and it assumes its natural color.]

sp.speaker: Drag.
sp.p: Stay! 'tis past. Hark!
sp.stage: [Stalacta is heard singing beneath the waters. All bend forward and listen.]

sp.speaker: Drag.
sp.p: 'Tis she, our Queen!

div.stage: [All kneel.] [Music. Stalacta rises rises (C.) from the water, slowly, and steps on shore, assisted by Dragonfin.]

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: Arise, my loving subjects.

sp.speaker: Drag.
sp.p: Mistress, but now the light in yon great sapphire died out, and stains of blood flushed in the face of the pale moon. You have 'scaped some deadly peril.

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: Thou art right. Listen, all. To-night, while wandering in the fastnesses of the Hartz, without my protecting talisman, I heedlessly trod within one of the charmed circles of our enemy, the arch-fiend Zamiel.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: On the instant I was transformed into a white dove, with shorn pinions. From beneath the rank leaves of an adder-plant glided a huge serpent. Its eyes were burning coals, its tongue a living flame. I was paralyzed with fear and powerless to move. Nearer and nearer it came. I felt its stifling breath displace the purer air. I saw its venomed fangs glistening in the pale moonlight. Rising from out its deadly coil, it poised itself to strike, when suddenly a youth, a mortal, strangely present in that wild, wierd spot, seeing the danger of the trembling bird, seized a dead bough, which chance had fashioned like a holy cross, and smote the foul thing dead, then bore me safely from the charmed spot and gave me life and liberty.

sp.speaker: Drag.
sp.p: Revenge! Revenge on the minions of Zamiel. [Goes quickly off R.H.U.E.]

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Revenge! Revenge!

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: Nay, let no thought other than of joy mingle with this happy time. Remember, 'tis my natal hour, and I would have it, as in the past, a festal one. Let the invisible Harmonies of this, our realm, breathe sweetest concord only; and you, bright Crystaline, with your fair sisters, chase with flying feet the silver hours.

div.stage: [Music. The fairies form for dance. After the first pose, a loud, prolonged warning note, as if from a shell, is heard outside. at back. All start in alarm, and hold the attitude of listening. The sound is repeated. Music. Hurry. The pose is broken, and the fairies, gnomes and amphibea, seizing their arms, form in alarm on either side. Dragonfin appears quickly through trap behind 1st set water and lands in front of ground piece.]

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.stage: [Who at the first sound has sprung to her feet.]
sp.p: Speak, what danger threatens?

sp.speaker: Drag.
sp.p: The sentinel shells, played upon by the watchful winds, give alarm! Two daring mortals, armed with the enchanted magnet of the Black Crook, approach the secret entrance. Already they have passed the white whirlpool in safety. They come to despoil our realm of its glittering wealth.

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Fear not the talisman they bear is powerless against the spells that guard the portal. Is my battalia at its post?

sp.speaker: Drag.
sp.p: The invisible guards of the entrance are marshalled for their destruction, and their white bones shall glisten far down among the red branches of the blood coral.

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: My faithful subjects, your Queen commends the zeal with which you would guard from mortal sight our beauteous realm ; but ere these rash intruders perish I would gratify a strange desire. Speed hence, good Dragonfin, catch me their shadows from the bosom of the moon-lighted lake, and cast them upon my faithful mirror. I would look upon them ere they fade forever.
sp.stage: [Music. Dragonfin prostrates him- self before Stalacta, springs into the water and disappears.]

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: Begin the spell.

div.stage: [Music. Dragonfin springs from the water, and, after prostrating himself before the Queen, rises and points to the water. Music. Fairies wave their wands. A small, arched-headed frame of gold and coral stalactites rises center at the distant entrance of the grotto, showing small figures of Rodolphe and Greppo in boat, the former at the prow, gazing anxiously forward ; the latter aft, in the attitude of paddling.

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.stage: [Who has crossed down R. H., turns when the picture is fully shown. Chord. Starting.]
sp.p: Ha, 'tis he! He must not perish. Invisible spirits, avert this peril.

div.stage: [Music. Hurry. The mirror and figures quickly sink.]

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: Dragonfin, come hither. Fly with swiftest speed to the rocks beneath the waters of the guarded entramce. When the frail bark which now approaches shall be rent asunder by the relentless spells that guard our realm, be it your task to snatch from death these daring mortals and bear them safely hither.
Mistress!

div.sp:
Stalacta
Nay, question me not, away, away.
Slaves of my power, obey, obey.
[Music. Hurry. Dragonfin bows low, springs into the water and disappears. MUSIC. A small boat with two mechanical figures, representing Rodolphe & Greppo as they appeared in the mirror, appears from R. H. outside, at the distant entrance of the grotto, and moves very slowly across; when it reaches the center of the opening it sinks at the sound of the gong and flash of lightning at back. Music. Hurry. All the gnomes, amphibia, etc., utter exclaminations of delight and indulge in extravagant antics, until checked by a gesture from Stalacta. Soft music. Dragonfin rises slowly from water (C), supporting on either side Rodolphe and Greppo, the latter gasping violently for breath as his head appears. They step on shore, Rodolphe and Greppo lost in bewilderment. Dragonfin bows low before Stalacta. The other amphibia and gnomes make a demonstration of attack.]
Forbear. Who moves again till I alone command, shall perish.\
[They retire.]

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: [Rubbing his eyes.] Is this a phantasm--this glittering gold, yon flashing gems, these strange, fantastic shapes? Have I, then, passed the portal of an unknown world, or am I dreaming?

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: Welcome, brave mortal, to our bright domain, and you, my subjects, know and greet your Queen's preserver.

div.stage: [Music. Gnomes and amphibia cluster around Rodolphe and Greppo, rolling at their feet and indulging in various grateful antics, after which the fairies surround them and evince their delight.]

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: [Still bewildered.] If this, indeed, be not a dream, tell me, bright being, you whose simple motion seems to sway the moods and passions of this elfin band, who art thou and where am I?

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: I am called Stalacta, Queen of this dazzling realm. The glittering wonders that assail thine eyes are not creations of fantastic dreams, but nature's handiwork, wrought with cunning fingers in a bounteous mood.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: [Who has picked up a large mass of gold at back, comes forward.] 'Tis true, master, 'tis true. Behold this shining nugget!

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: Who is thy droll companion?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: My simple henchman, a faithful guide and servitor!

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: I bid him welcome for his master's sake.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: Thanks, thanks, your resplendent majesty, thanks.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: You speak of service done; have we, then, met before?

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Yes, once.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Indeed! When?

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: This very night.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: To-night?

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: To-night, in the Glen of Fire; but not as now. Then, a poor weak, fluttering, charm-encompassed bird, you snatched me from the jaws of death, broke the dark spell of transformation, and gave to me the priceless boon of liberty.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: I do remember--

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: And so do I. Phew! how the sparks flew when master smashed the head of the scaly monster, and such a smell of brimstone! I do believe it was one of the Belzebub's own imps in disguise.

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: Again thou art welcome. This is my natal hour--wilt view the sports of this our carnival?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Most willingly.

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: And while the revels proceed thou shalt tell me thy story.

div.stage: [Music. Seats are brought forward by amphibia R.H. 1st ent.; Stalacta and Rodolphe sit ; Greppo disposes himself L. H. 1st ent., amusing himself with Dragonfin, gnomes and amphibia, who present him from time to time with nuggets of gold and jewels, which he thrusts into his pockets until they become greatly distended, during which action the diminutive sprites reappear in shells on water, floating to and fro, fishing. The fairies form for dance as at first. Grand ballet action by principals and full corps de ballet, during which the fishers in the shells are seen to catch small silver fish.

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: [Rising and leading Rodolphe forward.] Thy story claims for thee my pity and my aid.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: And Hertzog, the Black Crook--

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: Is a vile sorcerer, whose dark, unhallowed spells were wrought for thy destruction.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: Beneath the entrance to this charmed spot lie intertwined among the branches of the coraline whole hecatombs of human bones, the whitened relics of adventurous mortals who, like thyself, have sought this realm. Until to night, no human eye has ever seen the dazzling splendor of this wondrous dome ; no human footsteps save thine own and his who follows thee have ever pressed these sands of gold. Had not thy coming been to me forshadowed, and all my power been interposed to snatch thee from the impending doom, thou, too had'st joined the hapless throng that mouldering lies beneath yon depths.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Then is thy debt to me already paid.

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: Not so. I am still thy debtor, and must ever be. Thou art environed by danger, and need the power of my protection. Return unto the outer world again ; thy happiness is there. She whom thou lovest is worthy of thy love; therefore return.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Amina, dear Amina!

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: In the secret cells of this cavern, whose walls are solid gold, lie counteless hoards of richest treasure, gleaned for ages by the tireless gnomes. In the crystal depths of these waters sparkle gems richer by far than human eyes have ever gazed upon ; of these thou shalt bear with thee the choicest. Behold my gift!
sp.stage: [Music. A golden boat, studded with jewels, glides on from L. H. to L. C.]
sp.p: This bark, protected by a potent spell, loaded with rich and costly jewels, shall bear thee safely to yon neighboring shore. My faithful gnomes shall be thy treasure bearers. But ere we part take thou this jewelled circlet.
sp.stage: [Gives him a ring from her finger.]
sp.p: Should danger threaten, as perchance it will, for baffled malice has a thousand stings, press but thy lips upon the gem and thou wilt find me by thy side.
sp.stage: [Music. Rodolphe kneels and kisses her hand)

sp.speaker: Stal.
sp.p: Farewell!

div.stage: [Music. He steps into the boat ; Greppo, bearing a large mass of gold, affectionately embraces Dragonfin, shakes hands with the gnomes and amphibia, kisses the fairies, bows low to Stalacta and gets into the boat. A dolphin glittering in green and gold rises from behind 2d or 3d set water, with principal danseuse bearing a vase of treasure ; other dolphins float on R. and L., with diminutive sprites bearing treasure. Copious shower of gold, the other sprites on the water catching the flakes in silver shells. Poses by gnomes, amphibia and fairies. The whole scene brilliantly lighted. Tableaux and slow curtain.
Slow Curtain

div.head:
ACT 3.
A lapse of six months.
div.stage: Scene--Illuminated gardens of Wolfenstein by moonlight with terrace and illuminated castle at back, the latter half hidden by foilage. Set flowers and statuary R. and L. at back. Set low plant in front of trap R. H. 2d ent. Music at rise of curtain. Masqueraders in ball costume discovered promenading and conversing. Entrance and grand character dance by principals of the ballet, after which the masqueraderss gradually disappear at different entrances.
Enter from the terrace L.H. Madame Barbara, masked, flauntingly dressed and carrying a huge fan. She is followed by Carline.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: [Unmasking and coming forward.] Phew! what a relief. Thank the saints his Countship's birthday comes but once a year. Another such festival would be the death of me. Ah! I'm stewed, fried, boiled and roasted.

div.stage: Enter from terrace, L. H. Von Puffengruntz.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: There she is! What a grace! What a dignity! What a walk!
Ah-a-a!

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.stage: [L.R. gazes admiringly at her and sighs.]

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Heigho! There he is! My charms tonight have completed the conquest. He's fast bound in the bonds of rosy cupid. I see a proposal in one eye and a marriage settlement in the other, But I mustn't draw him in too suddenly. These men are like trout--they must be played with a little.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Full moon of the festival, why have you so cruelly robbed the grand hall of your light, and left us to grope about in the dull glimmer of the sickly stars.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Don't talk to me about moonshine and sickly stars, you heartless, gay deceiver.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Deceiver?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Deceiver! Did'st I see you gallivanting with the fraulein Von Scragneck, the new Burgonmaster's daughter?

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Politeness, my dear madam Barbara, merely politeness on my honor. The fact is, I-I had the misfortune to tread on the lady's favorite bunion, and what you mistook for tenderness was only an apology-an apology, believe me, my dear madam Barbara, only an apology.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh, you men, you deceiving men, you are always ready with an excuse.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: On the honor of a Von Puffengruntz, I swear I speak the truth. The fraulein Von Skragneck, indeed! Haven't I got eyes? Ah, cruel fair one, compared with her and all others, you are as the stately sunflower in a meadow of dandelions; As--as--as the queen hollyhock in a garden of chickweed.

div.stage: [Music. Tremulo piano. Dragonfin ascends quietly through trap behind low set plant R. H. 2nd ent., steps forward and listens.]

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: It's coming at last, I know it's coming. [pressing her heart,] what a strange flutter; I hope I'm not going to faint ; dear me, what poor, weak, silly creatures we are ; I must nerve myself for the trying occasion. How fortunate it is that I happen to have my smelling salts about me, [draws flask from her pocket, turns her back to Von Puff. and drinks.]

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: She's moved, she's overcome with emotion, she turns away to hide her blushes. She yields! and now, like a conqueror, I'll gather in the fruits of victory.
sp.stage: [He kneels with difficulty at the feet of Barbara, his face half averted, and is about to take her hand, when Dragonfin glides quietly between them, extends his left hand to Von Puffengruntz, and takes Barbara's in the other; then both sigh)

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.stage: [Squeezing the hand of Dragonfin, who shakes with suppressed laughter.]
sp.p: Poor, frightened thing, how she trembles.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Dear me, how strangely the tender passion affects him, he's shaking like an aspen, and his hand is as cold as ice.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Bewitching syren, listen to the voice of love.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh, mynheer Von Puffengruntz, how can you?

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Don't call me Von Puffengruntz, call me Maximillian, call me your Maximillian, [Squeezes Dragonfin's hand, Dragonfin squeezes Barbara's.]

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Oh, don't, you naughty man, you--you hurt my hand.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: No, did I, queen of love and beauty! then let me heal the bruise. [kisses the hand of Dragonfin rapturously who at the same time kisses Barbara's.] And now that I've healed it, let me call it mine. [looks for the first time attentively at the hand, continues inspection up the arm until he encounters the grinning face of Dragonfin, when in speechless terror he drops the hand, makes various floundering attempts to regain his feet, and exits hurriedly L.H. 1st Ent.]

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: [Aside.] Shall I keep him a little longer with cupid's dart sticking in his bosom, or shall I end his misery? [Aloud,] Ahem! you'll-you'll never be a naughty boy again!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And you'll promise never to tread on the fraulein Von Skragneck's favorite bunion?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Poor fellow, joy has made him speechless ; he can only answer with a squeeze of the hand,
Well then, Maximillian, I'm yours.

div.stage: [falls into Dragonfins's arms, looks up into his face. Music, chord and hurry--she utters a piercing scream and rushes off R.H. 1st ent. Dragonfin indulges in extravagant antics until music changes, when he starts, inclines his ear to the ground and listens, rises, moves cautiously to R.H. 1st ent. ; starts, points off R.H., shakes his clenched hand threateningly, and quickly disappears through trap R.H.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: [Entering R.H. 1st ent. hurriedly and disturbed.] Foiled, tricked, crossed in the hour of my victory. A life desperately played for and fairly won, snatched from the jaws of death. He lives! My chosen victim lives, and flushed with triumph and vast hoards of gold, stalks boldly forth to mock me. Oh, curse the interposing power that stepped between us. A withering palsy light upon her arm, and blight and pestilence infect the air she breathes! Oh, impotent, driveling fool! To work! To work! A soul once tempered with must be pursued, not cast aside to tempt another. So runs the bond to which I've sealed. 'Tis well! 'Tis well! I'll track him as the sleuth-hound tracks the stag! He must, he shall be mine.

div.stage: [Music,] exit L.H. 1st ent.

[Enter from terrace L.H. Rodolphe and Amina. He is brilliantly dressed, wearing a collar and other ornaments of glittering jewels, blue mask and domino. Amina also wears mask and domino. Rodolphe and Amina unmask.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Oh, dear Rodolphe, is this a dream?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: What's past seems so ; but day has dawned on our long-clouded night, and this the awakening.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Your story is indeed most wondrous. But oh, dear Rodolphe, I tremble for your life. If you should be discovered, the vengeance of the ruthless Wolfenstein, backed by his horde of fierce retainers, would be most terrible.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Fear not. I will defend my right with my life. The same kind power that interposed between me and destruction protects us still. You shall be saved. All is ready for our flight. On the border of the forest, beyond the boundary of the gardens, swift horses are concealed. After midnight, the moon, veiling her face behind the Brocken, will throw a deep shadow over the valley. When all is quiet, I will be beneath your window--the rest is easy. Carline and my faithful Greppo will accompany us.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: [Throwing her arms around him.] Oh, my Rodolphe, my more than life! Coming thus suddenly from the darkness of my despair into the sunlight of this new-born hope dazzles me; my eyelids close; I cannot look this great joy in the face; I fear to call it mine.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Fear?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Fear with that fear that springs from woman's love.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Be calm, sweet love. Be brave, and all will yet be well.

div.stage: [Music. Piano. Laughter heard outside at back.]

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Hark! The masquers come this way. Let's mingle with the throng.
sp.stage: [They mask and cross to L.H. 1st ent.]

div.stage: [Music. Louder. Masquers enter L. and R., laughing and conversing. While so engaged, and after all are on, music changes to hurry. Hertzog with drawn sword, enters hurriedly at terrace, L.H., followed quickly by guards. Wolfenstein with drawn sword, Wulfgar, Bruno, and last Von Puffengruntz and Barbara, the two latter remaining on terrace. Hertzog R.H. 1st ent., glaring at Rodolphe.]

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: [C. at foot of steps] Let no one stir. Guard every avenue that leads from hence. [To guests.] Bear with me, friends, there's treason in our midst.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Treason!

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: 'Tis said a serf, a wretch, usurping the semblance of a noble prince, and bent on outrage has dared to mingle with this goodly throng. If this be false, to all I'll make amends for this rude breaking in upon the general joy. If it be true, 'tis fit we know it, therefore I do command that all shall here unmask.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Lost, Lost!

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Aye, let all unmask!

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: 'Tis true! Yield, audacious miscreant!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Never, while life remains.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: Upon him, guards! hew him to pieces!

div.stage: [Music. Ladies scream, Amina faints is caught in the arms of Greppo, who enters L.H. 1st ent. Wolfenstein, Wulfar, Bruno and guards are rushing upon Rodolphe.]

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p: The Ring, master, the Ring.

div.stage: [Rodolphe kisses the ring; Lights up quick ; Stalacta springs from L. H. 1st ent.,in glittering mail, with helmet, sword and shield, followed by Dragonfin, armed with a trident ; gnomes and amphibea with knotted clubs and tridents form L. H. 2d and 3d entrances, and and on terrace R. and L. ; Fairies and Nymps as Amazons, with breast plates, shields, helmets and javalins, from L. H. 1st ent. Wolfenstein, guards and gentlemen shrink back appalled. Herzog stands the embodiment of baffled rage. Von Puffengruntz on terrace faints and falls into the arms of Barbara, who fans him. Tableaux and quick curtain.]

Note--From the cue "hew him to pieces.", the whole action must be hurried and simultaneous ; foot and stage lights flashed quickly up when Rodolphe kisses the ring. When curtain drops first time hold the picture to answer encore.

div.head:
Act 4.
A lapse of six months.
div.stage: Scene I.--An apartment in the castle of Wolfenstein. (In 1.)
[Music. Enter Barbara, R.H.]

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Alas that things ever fall so ill. 'Tis now six months since that never-to-be-forgotten night and still no news of the lost mistress of Wolfenstein ; nor yet of his lordship who has sworn an oath never to return to the castle until he has brought her back, and revenged himself on the horrible monster who has stolen her. And that graceless baggage, Carline, too, to go off at the same time, leaving all the cares of the household to fall on my poor shoulders ; and then to make the matter worse, spells and witchcraft turn all things upside down. The cows milk vinegar. The wells are dry. The hens lay haddled eggs.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: [Entering R.H. with a very red nose and tipsey.] And all the wine's turned sour.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: [Looking ruefully at him.] There's another comfort. To think that I, the right honorable foster-mother that was to have been, to her right honorable ladyship that was to have been ; for whom many a young and tender heart has sighed in vain, should ever have thrown herself away upon a wine butt.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: A wine-butt, Madam Van Puffengruntz?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Aye, a wine-butt--a beer barrel--a brute that hasn't drawn a sober breath since the day we were married, now more than three months ago.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: A beer-barrel!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: [Savagely.] I said a beer-barrel.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
Barbara
sp.p: Cackle?

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Cackle, my dear. You know I never have a moment's peace. You're not even quiet when you're asleep ; you snore, Madam Von Puffengrunz, you snore, loud enough to split the drum of my ear and rip up the seam up my night-cap.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Snore! you wretch! I snore?

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, and have the night-mare. [Hic.] I don't like a wife that snores, and I hate a wife that has the night-mare. In future, I am going to have separate apartments. Hereafter, I intend to sleep alone.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Alone?

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: I said alone.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Am I awake? Who and what do you take me for?

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.p: I took you for a gentle spice--a sort of seasoning to the dull life I led here in the castle--but damn it, Madam, you've turned out to be all the condiments in one--a bottom layer of mustard, a top dressing of cayenne pepper, and a subeterranean lake of vinegar in the middle.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: [Enraged and approaching him--he retreats around L. H.] Cackle! snore! nightmare! separate apartments! cayenne pepper! You wretch! You--you sot! you villain! I'll pepper you! [Pulls his wig off.] There! take that! and that! and that! [Beats him over the poll with it 'till both off L.H.]

div.stage: Curtain

div.head: Scene II.--The retreat of Rodolphe in the Forest of Bohemia. (in 2.) [Music.] Distant sound of a hunter's horn and echo. Enter L. H. U. E. Rodolphe and Amina, followed by Greppo. The two first are in hunting costume.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: [Throwing his spear and horn to Greppo.] I weary with the chase. Call together our people and bid them lead our horses to where the forest path crosses the brook. There we will join them.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: 'Tis wisely resolved, good master. The sun declines, and night comes on apace, and we are yet some three good miles from home, besides, I'm hollow as a drum. Moreover, in early autumn venison keeps not over long, and the fat haunch of yonder noble stag cries out for speedy roasting. Pray do not tarry long.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Well, dear love, to-morrow ends the year of our probation. Tomorrow, at the holy altar's foot, I call you mine.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: To-morrow! How brief the time, and yet how long 'till then! Oh, Rodolphe, will it come to us? There seems to be a lurking danger in the air--a cloud between us and the coming light.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Fear not. Here in the deep seculsion of our forest home, we are safe from all pursuit. [Distant horn and echo L. H. at back.] Hark! 'tis Greppo calling in the huntsmen. Let's on to meet them.

div.stage: [Music. They are crossing to R. H. when they are suddenly confronted by Hertzog, Wolfenstein and Wulfgar, who enter quickly R.H. 2d ent. Chord.]

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! At last we meet!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: [Starting back and drawing his sword.] Entrapped! Fly, Amina! seek safety with our people. My arm shall bar pursuit!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: No, Rodolphe, we will die together!

sp.speaker: Wolf.
sp.p: Alive! Take him alive! Yield!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: [Standing on his defense.] He who takes my sword must win it.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Put up thy blade. She whom thou wouldst invoke is powerless to aid.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p:
False wretch! But that another life hangs on the slender thread of mine, though coward numbers swarmed on every side, I'd try this issue with my single sword. But know thou still art juggled with. The power I once invoked is potent still.
[Music. He kisses the ring. Stalacta springs from the thicket L.H. flat, in glittering full armor, Dragonfin on from L.H. 2d ent.)
Behold! we meet on equal ground!

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: Though environed by a thousand fiends, my hate would find a way to reach you.

div.stage: [Music. Grand triple sword combat. Rodolphe and Wolfenstein, Stalacta and Hertzog, Dragonfin and Wulfgar. Wolfenstein and Wulfgar are slain. Hertzog, wounded and dismayed, flies R.H. 2d ent. Amina, who during the combat has knelt in prayer, throws herself into the arms of Rodolphe ; then both kneel at the feet of Stalacta. Dragonfin indulges in grotesque exultation over the bodies of Wolfenstein and Wulfgar. Picture closed in.]

div.head: Scene III.--The forest in 1.
div.stage: [Music. Enter R. H. Rodolphe supporting Amina.]

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Look up, Amina. All danger's past. Courage. Ere long we'll meet our people.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: And you are safe?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Safe. Come, poor trembling dove--courage, courage.

div.stage: Music. Enter R. H. Hertzog, infuriate.

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Let one vast curse fill all the air! Am I, then, juggled with? Malignant powers, obey your master's call! Viewless spirits of evil, work now your direst spells! As toppling mountains crush the mighty pines, crush thou the power that thwarts and mocks me. Zamiel, mighty master, I invoke thy aid!
sp.stage: [Music. Thunder. Two fiends enter quickly R. and L., bearing lighted flambeaux.]

sp.speaker: Fiends.
sp.p: Your will?

sp.speaker: Hert.
sp.p: Summon your infernal legions ; pursue yon flying pair. Fire the forest, girdle them with a belt of flame, close every avenue of escape. Away, away!

div.stage: [Music. Thunder. Fiends salaam and rush off L.H., followed by Hertzog. Change.]

div.head: Scene IV.--
div.stage: A burning forest. A grand and imposing conflagation scene (in 2.) Lights down. Music at opening of scene. Loud crackling noise (torpedoes) and red fire on both sides. Rodolphe and Amina enter L.H. 2d ent. ; as they attempt to escape they are driven back from R. and L. by fiends with flaming torches.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: [In agony.] I burn! I suffocate!

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.p: Courage! Courage! The Ring! The Ring!

div.stage: [He kisses the ring; gong sounds; a rock opens in L.H. flat, disclosing a grotto of silver stalactites; they quickly enter ; Hertzog and the fiends spring forward, when Stalacta steps forth from the opening, holding aloft a glittering cross; Hertzog and the fiends shrink back and run off ; Tableaux closed in.

div.head: Scene V.--The forest by night in 1 ; lights down ; Sound of huntersr' horn and very faint echo. Greppo enters R. H.

sp.speaker: Grep.
sp.p:
What's the use? Now what is the use? The oftener I call the fainter comes the answer. Here it is quite dark. Master waiting for the horses and I wandering about like a jack o' lantern, following the horn of some goblin huntsman. There's some devil's work going on. [Starting.]
I beg his infernal Majesty's pardon. I hope I have not said anything to offend ; but strange sights and sounds are in the air. Birds that ought to have been to roost an hour ago, fly screaming from tree to tree. The dismal screech-owl, from its hole in the oak, answers to the croak of the dreary monk-raven ; and just now I saw a big fat buck scampering through the forest with his tail on fire. Oh dear! Oh dear! what fearful omens! And I'm to be married to-morrow. If anything should happen to me! If my poor, dear, darling little Carline should happen to be left a widow before she's made a wife--if I should never taste--that is, if I should never know--Oh, Lord! it won't bear thinking of. I'll try once more. [Minds the horn. Echo scarce audible.] Worse and worse. Oh Lord! Oh Lord! I want to go home! [Exit L. H. change.])

div.head: Scene VI.--
div.stage: Pandemonium (in 2 or 3). Zamiel in council, seated on an illuminated throne of skulls and flame, C; at back to R. and L. of C, lesser thrones, that on the right occupied by Red Glare, the recording demon, with pen and open book ; that on the left by a secretary writing ; at the foot of the throne two dwarf demons; pages with wands in attendance.

Music at opening of scene! Fiends discovered in a chorus of demoniacal yells, and fiendish laughter, dancing around a flaming chasm. After the action is continued a brief time, Zamiel waves his sceptre. Demons separate and form R. and L.

sp.speaker: Zam.
sp.p: 'Tis well. Let silence reign awhile. How stands the record of the dying year? Has every seed brought sinful fruit--is all the harvest gathered in--is every bond fulfilled?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: All, all save one!

sp.speaker: Zam.
sp.p: Who plays the laggard?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: One who sought to rival thy great power. Hertzog, the Black Crook!

sp.speaker: All the Fiends
sp.p: Ho! ho! ho!
sp.stage: [Echoed without and within, followed by a single wild blast of infernal music.]

sp.speaker: Zam.
sp.p: If, when the brazen tongue of clamorous time, now trembling on the midnight's verge, proclaims the appointed hour, the wail of no fresh soul by him betrayed breaks on the air of Hell, let him be summoned!

div.stage: [Music. The demons utter a wild wail of delight and resume the dance. The gong strikes twleve. At the first stroke the demons cease dancing, and hold separate pictures of exulatation. At the termination of each stroke a single brazen blast of demoniacal music. At the twelfth stroke, loud and continued thunder. Demons utter a wild cry ; Zamiel rises, waves his sceptre. (If possible, the scene breaks away and discovers vistas of Pandemonium, in 3, teeming with infernal life and wreaths of flame, from which appear illuminated heads of demons, skeletons, and nondescript monsters.) Gong sounds. Hertzog is dragged on from R.H. by fiends and is dashed into burning chasm which opens. Demons howl and dance around till closed in.

div.head: Scene VIII.--
div.stage: [Music at opening.] An elaborate mechanical and scenical construction of the Realms of Stalacta, occupying the entire stage. This scene must be of gradually developing and culminating beauty, introducing, during its various transformations, Stalacta, the entire host of fairies, sprites, water nymphs, amphibea, gnomes, etc., bearing treasure. Rodolphe and Amina, Greppo and Carline. Calcium lights, brilliant fires and slow curtain. Draphin car descends.
